header.title: crypto

description.p: This module provides a set of cryptographic functions.

item.p: md4: The MD4 Message Digest Algorithm (RFC 1320)
md5: The MD5 Message Digest Algorithm (RFC 1321)
ecb, cbc, cfb, ofb, ctr: Recommendation for Block Cipher Modes of Operation (NIST SP 800-38A).
rsa: Recommendation for Block Cipher Modes of Operation (NIST 800-38A)

description.p: The above publications can be found at NIST publications, at IETF.
description.pre: byte() = 0 ... 255 ioelem() = byte() | binary() | iolist() iolist() = [ioelem()] Mpint() = <<ByteLen:32/integer-big, Bytes:ByteLen/binary>>

func.name: des_cbc_encrypt(Key, IVec, Text) -> Cipher
func.fsummary: Encrypt Textaccording to DES in CBC mode

desc.p: Encrypts Text according to DES in CBC mode. Text must be a multiple of 64 bits (8 bytes). Key is the DES key, and IVec is an arbitrary initializing vector. The lengths of Key and IVec must be 64 bits (8 bytes).

func.name: des_cbc_decrypt(Key, IVec, Cipher) -> Text
func.fsummary: Decrypt Cipheraccording to DES in CBC mode

desc.p: Decrypts Cipher according to DES in CBC mode. Key is the DES key, and IVec is an arbitrary initializing vector. Key and IVec must have the same values as those used when encrypting. Cipher must be a multiple of 64 bits (8 bytes). The lengths of Key and IVec must be 64 bits (8 bytes).

func.name: des_cbc_ivec(Data) -> IVec
func.fsummary: Get IVec to be used in next iteration of des_cbc_[ecrypt|decrypt]

desc.p: Returns the IVec to be used in a next iteration of des_cbc_[encrypt|decrypt]. Data is the encrypted data from the previous iteration step.

func.name: des3_cbc_encrypt(Key1, Key2, Key3, IVec, Text) -> Cipher
func.fsummary: Encrypt Textaccording to DES3 in CBC mode

desc.p: Encrypts Text according to DES3 in CBC mode. Text must be a multiple of 64 bits (8 bytes). Key1, Key2, Key3, are the DES keys, and IVec is an arbitrary initializing vector. The lengths of each of Key1, Key2, Key3 and IVec must be 64 bits (8 bytes).

func.name: des3_cbc_decrypt(Key1, Key2, Key3, IVec, Cipher) -> Text
func.fsummary: Decrypt Cipheraccording to DES in CBC mode

type.v: Key1 = Key2 = Key3 = Cipher = iolist() | binary()

desc.p: Decrypts Cipher according to DES3 in CBC mode. Key1, Key2, Key3 are the DES key, and IVec is an arbitrary initializing vector. Key1, Key2, Key3 and IVec must and IVec must have the same values as those used when encrypting. Cipher must be a multiple of 64 bits (8 bytes). The lengths of Key1, Key2, Key3, and IVec must be 64 bits (8 bytes).

func.name: aes_cfb_128_encrypt(Key, IVec, Text) -> Cipher
aes_cbc_128_encrypt(Key, IVec, Text) -> Cipher

func.name: aes_cfb_128_decrypt(Key, IVec, Cipher) -> Text
aes_cbc_128_decrypt(Key, IVec, Cipher) -> Text

func.fsummary: Get IVec to be used in next iteration of aes_cbc_*_[ecrypt|decrypt]

func.fsummary: Decrypt Cipheraccording to AES in Counter mode

func.name: erlint(Mpint) -> N
mpint(N) -> Mpint
func.fsummary: Convert between binary multi-precision integer and erlang big integer

desc.p: Convert a binary multi-precision integer Mpint to and from an erlang big integer. A multi-precision integer is a binary with the following form: <<ByteLen:32/integer, Bytes:ByteLen/binary>> where both ByteLen and Bytes are big-endian. Mpints are used in some of the functions in crypto and are not translated in the API for performance reasons.

func.name: rand_bytes(N) -> binary()
func.fsummary: Generate a binary of random bytes

desc.p: Generates N bytes randomly uniform 0..255, and returns the result in a binary. Uses the crypto library pseudo-random number generator.

func.name: rand_uniform(Lo, Hi) -> N
func.fsummary: Generate a random number

desc.p: Generate a random number N, Lo =< N < Hi. Uses the crypto library pseudo-random number generator. The arguments (and result) can be either erlang integers or binary multi-precision integers.

func.name: mod_exp(N, P, M) -> Result
func.fsummary: Perform N ^ P mod M

desc.p: This function performs the exponentiation N ^ P mod M, using the crypto library.

func.name: rsa_sign(Data, Key) -> Signature
rsa_sign(DigestType, Data, Key) -> Signature
func.fsummary: Sign the data using rsa with the given key.

type.d: Where E is the public exponent, N is public modulus and D is the private exponent.

desc.p: Calculates a DigestType digest of the Data and creates a RSA signature with the private key Key of the digest.

func.name: rsa_verify(Data, Signature, Key) -> Verified
rsa_verify(DigestType, Data, Signature, Key) -> Verified
func.fsummary: Verify the digest and signature using rsa with given public key.

type.d: Where E is the public exponent and N is public modulus.

desc.p: Calculates a DigestType digest of the Data and verifies that the digest matches the RSA signature using the signer's public key Key.

func.name: rsa_public_encrypt(PlainText, PublicKey, Padding) -> ChipherText
func.fsummary: Encrypts Msg using the public Key.

type.d: Where E is the public exponent and N is public modulus.

desc.p: Encrypts the PlainText (usually a session key) using the PublicKey and returns the cipher. The Padding decides what padding mode is used, rsa_pkcs1_padding is PKCS #1 v1.5 currently the most used mode and rsa_pkcs1_oaep_padding is EME-OAEP as defined in PKCS #1 v2.0 with SHA-1, MGF1 and an empty encoding parameter. This mode is recommended for all new applications. The size of the Msg must be less than byte_size(N)-11 if rsa_pkcs1_padding is used, byte_size(N)-41 if rsa_pkcs1_oaep_padding is used and byte_size(N) if rsa_no_padding is used. Where byte_size(N) is the size part of an Mpint-1.

func.name: rsa_private_decrypt(ChipherText, PrivateKey, Padding) -> PlainText
func.fsummary: Decrypts ChipherText using the private Key.

type.d: Where E is the public exponent, N is public modulus and D is the private exponent.

desc.p: Decrypts the ChipherText (usually a session key encrypted with rsa_public_encrypt/3) using the PrivateKey and returns the message. The Padding is the padding mode that was used to encrypt the data, see rsa_public_encrypt/3.

func.name: rsa_private_encrypt(PlainText, PrivateKey, Padding) -> ChipherText
func.fsummary: Encrypts Msg using the private Key.

type.d: Where E is the public exponent, N is public modulus and D is the private exponent.

desc.p: Encrypts the PlainText using the PrivateKey and returns the cipher. The Padding decides what padding mode is used, rsa_pkcs1_padding is PKCS #1 v1.5 currently the most used mode. The size of the Msg must be less than byte_size(N)-11 if rsa_pkcs1_padding is used, and byte_size(N) if rsa_no_padding is used. Where byte_size(N) is the size part of an Mpint-1.

func.name: rsa_public_decrypt(ChipherText, PublicKey, Padding) -> PlainText
func.fsummary: Decrypts ChipherText using the public Key.

type.d: Where E is the public exponent and N is public modulus

desc.p: Decrypts the ChipherText (encrypted with rsa_private_encrypt/3) using the PrivateKey and returns the message. The Padding is the padding mode that was used to encrypt the data, see rsa_private_encrypt/3.

func.name: dss_sign(Data, Key) -> Signature
dss_sign(DigestType, Data, Key) -> Signature
func.fsummary: Sign the data using dsa with given private key.

type.d: Where P, Q and G are the dss parameters and X is the private key.

desc.p: Creates a DSS signature with the private key Key of a digest. If DigestType is 'sha', the digest is calculated as SHA1 of Data. If DigestType is 'none', Data is the precalculated SHA1 digest.

func.name: dss_verify(Data, Signature, Key) -> Verified
dss_verify(DigestType, Data, Signature, Key) -> Verified
func.fsummary: Verify the data and signature using dsa with given public key.

type.d: Where P, Q and G are the dss parameters and Y is the public key.

desc.p: Verifies that a digest matches the DSS signature using the public key Key. If DigestType is 'sha', the digest is calculated as SHA1 of Data. If DigestType is 'none', Data is the precalculated SHA1 digest.

func.name: rc4_encrypt(Key, Data) -> Result
func.fsummary: Encrypt data using RC4

desc.p: Encrypts the data with RC4 symmetric stream encryption. Since it is symmetric, the same function is used for decryption.

func.name: dh_generate_key(DHParams) -> {PublicKey,PrivateKey}
dh_generate_key(PrivateKey, DHParams) -> {PublicKey,PrivateKey}
func.fsummary: Generates a Diffie-Hellman public key

type.d: Where P is the shared prime number and G is the shared generator.

desc.p: Generates a Diffie-Hellman PublicKey and PrivateKey (if not given).

func.name: dh_compute_key(OthersPublicKey, MyPrivateKey, DHParams) -> SharedSecret
func.fsummary: Computes the shared secret

type.d: Where P is the shared prime number and G is the shared generator.

desc.p: Computes the shared secret from the private key and the other party's public key.

func.name: exor(Data1, Data2) -> Result
func.fsummary: XOR data

desc.p: Performs bit-wise XOR (exclusive or) on the data supplied.

section.title: DES in CBC mode
section.p: The Data Encryption Standard (DES) defines an algorithm for encrypting and decrypting an 8 byte quantity using an 8 byte key (actually only 56 bits of the key is used).

When it comes to encrypting and decrypting blocks that are multiples of 8 bytes various modes are defined (NIST SP 800-38A). One of those modes is the Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) mode, where the encryption of an 8 byte segment depend not only of the contents of the segment itself, but also on the result of encrypting the previous segment: the encryption of the previous segment becomes the initializing vector of the encryption of the current segment.

Thus the encryption of every segment depends on the encryption key (which is secret) and the encryption of the previous segment, except the first segment which has to be provided with an initial initializing vector. That vector could be chosen at random, or be a counter of some kind. It does not have to be secret.

The following example is drawn from the old FIPS 81 standard (replaced by NIST SP 800-38A), where both the plain text and the resulting cipher text is settled. The following code fragment returns `true'.
section.pre:
Key = <<16#01,16#23,16#45,16#67,16#89,16#ab,16#cd,16#ef>>, IVec = <<16#12,16#34,16#56,16#78,16#90,16#ab,16#cd,16#ef>>, P = "Now is the time for all ", C = crypto:des_cbc_encrypt(Key, IVec, P), % Which is the same as P1 = "Now is t", P2 = "he time ", P3 = "for all ", C1 = crypto:des_cbc_encrypt(Key, IVec, P1), C2 = crypto:des_cbc_encrypt(Key, C1, P2), C3 = crypto:des_cbc_encrypt(Key, C2, P3),
C = <<C1/binary, C2/binary, C3/binary>>, C = <<16#e5,16#c7,16#cd,16#de,16#87,16#2b,16#f2,16#7c, 16#43,16#e9,16#34,16#00,16#8c,16#38,16#9c,16#0f, 16#68,16#37,16#88,16#49,16#9a,16#7c,16#05,16#f6>>, <<"Now is the time for all ">> == crypto:des_cbc_decrypt(Key, IVec, C).
section.p: The following is true for the DES CBC mode. For all decompositions P1 ++ P2 = P of a plain text message P (where the length of all quantities are multiples of 8 bytes), the encryption C of P is equal to C1 ++ C2, where C1 is obtained by encrypting P1 with Key and the initializing vector IVec, and where C2 is obtained by encrypting P2 with Key and the initializing vector last8(C1), where last(Binary) denotes the last 8 bytes of the binary Binary.

Similarly, for all decompositions C1 ++ C2 = C of a cipher text message C (where the length of all quantities are multiples of 8 bytes), the decryption P of C is equal to P1 ++ P2, where P1 is obtained by decrypting C1 with Key and the initializing vector IVec, and where P2 is obtained by decrypting C2 with Key and the initializing vector last8(C1), where last8(Binary) is as above.
For DES3 (which uses three 64 bit keys) the situation is the same.
